name: Alon–Saks–Seymour conjecture
rephrased: A graph with chromatic number k+1 requires at least k complete bipartite subgraphs in any edge-partition.
implication_form: If a graph has chromatic number k+1, then it requires at least k complete bipartite subgraphs to cover its edges (in any edge-partition).
posed_by: Noga Alon, Michael Saks, Paul Seymour
explained: The Alon–Saks–Seymour conjecture proposed that if a graph's edges can be partitioned into m edge-disjoint complete bipartite graphs, then the graph's chromatic number is at most m + 1. A key related statement is that a graph formed by the edge-disjoint union of m complete bipartite graphs is (m + 1)-colorable. This conjecture was later shown to be false, with counterexamples found in 2012.
